ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: randomized experiments
Randomised experiment design, analysis and interpretation. Less of a coding focus than I would have expected, but a solid understanding of the theory.

Designing and evaluating randomized field experiments; reading and critically discussing political science randomized experiment papers; use of R for data cleaning and visualization (tidyverse!) and random inference

I learned a-lot of R skills as well as how to run a good political randomized experiment. I also learned how to critically evaluate other experiments as well as acquired a lot of knowledge about statistical practices.
I gained a broad understanding of experimental design and implementation, especially in the social sciences.
I learned about randomized experiments and data analysis in depth
I learned about the theory and application of randomized field experiments, and honed my R skills!
I learned the basic theory and methodology behind randomized experiments. I also got more experience using the R coding language.
Learned a ton about randomized experiments in the social sciences both in terms of theory and application in R.
I learned how to critically approach and thoughtfully design social science studies, keeping principles such as unobserved heterogeneity and experimental bias in mind. I also learned some R!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: having a piazza would be great

Prof. Coppock's lectures match the textbook/readings very well so it's all fairly easy to follow. The final project is a fun way to tie everything we've learned together, although it does feel at times as though the course only skims the surface of the topic. Then again, it's more of a gateway course so the overview approach makes sense.

Strengths - Professor Coppock is a phenomenal lecturer, an incredibly clear coder (and uses tidyverse, which is all too rare in the SDS department), and an interesting person to talk to. He knows what he's talking about and is clearly passionate about it. I found lecture engaging, particularly on the days that we talked about papers. I appreciate how he would reinforce a concept many times, bringing it up again and again and reminding us about how important it is. I learned a lot in this class that I will remember for a long time.

Weaknesses - The workload of this course is not evenly spaced out over the semester. Psets drastically range in difficulty (but are overall fair and interesting). I think the biggest issue was when we had to start doing our final project at the same time that we were doing psets - the preanalysis plan was a lot of work, and I was completely swamped that week. It's good that the final project is spread out over so much time (forces you to start early!), but it's hard to balance alongside all the readings, papers, and psets you're also doing for the class at the same time.

I learned so much in this course! Professor Coppock is wonderful as is Liz. It felt relevant and applicable and gives really valuable skills in the 21st century. The only weakness is that sometimes expectations weren't clear from the start and students were left without much guidance, such as on the final paper (it was sprung on us a bit). I also thought it didn't make a ton of sense to have a final exam given the pulse of students mental and emotional states by that point in the COVID semester.

Prof. Coppock is an excellent instructor, and Liz is an excellent teaching fellow. Both Prof. Coppock and Liz made themselves available to students on a weekly basis, and each showed an interest in getting to know students better.

Everything about this class was great!! The psets were reasonable and very helpful, the final experiment was really fun and Professor Coppock is amazing. The only weakness was probably the final exam, which was a little tougher than I anticipated.
Very well-structured course, and Alex explains the theory very well. The R felt a little fast-paced at times.
The course is structured very well to provide training in three different areas: RCT theory, RCT applications, and coding. I can not think of any weaknesses.

strengths: professor coppock is great and really wants students to learn, the content is interesting, the class is well organized
weaknesses: there were some topics that we spent a lot of time on that I think we should have spent less time on and vice versa

This is a wonderful course. The general design (the first class of the week is usually on a section from the textbook, the second class is on a randomized social science study that utilizes the concepts the textbook section explored, the weekly section gives instruction in R, and weekly problem sets go over everything covered that week) is a definite strengthit allowed us to ground theory in practice, which made everything more understandable and more fun. Professor Coppock is also, of course, a strength. His excitement about the material is infectious, and his kindness makes for a welcoming class environment. The final project was also greatit was exciting to put everything we learned into practice! Regarding improvements for the future, a bit more clarity over which concepts from the textbook were not necessary to study closely (the textbooks method of constructing confidence intervals, for example, which we didnt use in class) might have made for slightly more efficient work (but this is a very small thing).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lectures were recorded, section was very well structured.

The lectures where we went over the papers were always engaging because Professor Coppock would call on students randomly to ask them for a fact about the paper, which we'd then unpack. The theoretical lecturers were less engaging and somewhat harder to follow, but I always appreciated when we'd pause and go through an example together as a class.

I thought it worked really well to ask people questions in the Wednesday class when we discussed readings. This kept everyone engaged. Also, when we solved problems together. Again, the only thing to improve was being a bit more cognizant and understanding of the kind of semester it was in terms of the final exam... it felt a little tone deaf.
I honestly feel like this class handled the virtual setting better than any of my other classes. Professor Coppock knew how to keep us engaged in the class in a low-stress way.
I though the course was structured as best as it could be for virtual learning.

I felt engaged in this course, which was taught completely online. I was grateful for Professor Coppocks gentle cold calling and expressed desire for cameras on, which definitely contributed to general class engagement.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yes
Yes!  A great intro to experimental design, really increases your appreciation and understanding of research.

Absolutely! Don't worry if you're not a plsc major or don't know R. This is a fun, engaging class where you learn a lot of useful things, but the workload is fair and relatively light. Lectures alternate between theoretical days and paper days, and section is always a review of coding. Psets are out of a textbook and interesting and straightforward. You have complete freedom with your final project. The class is worth it for the exposure to tidyverse alone, which is not often talked about in R classes but is what most people in the professional world use. You also get a full exposure to why we care about randomized experimental designs, how they're implemented, and potential problems. I would recommend going to office hours to get the most out of this class. It truly was an enjoyable time.

Yes! I think Coppock and Liz are great teachers and you will learn a lot and feel supported in the challenging content, which is a rare combination. Psets are fun and the final experiment was enjoyable too.

I would definitely recommend this class!! I took this class as a BA elective for the S&Ds major. It served as a really good refresher for concepts I had learned from other classes but didnt fully understand.
Yes! Solid course with real-world applications.
Yes! Professor Coppock is wonderful and the class provides a generative structure for learning statistics and research methods.
Yes, I would and I have recommended this course. I believe it is a great way to be introduced to an important, growing field within the social sciences.
definitely for students interested in social science research and who want to improve their coding skills

I would definitely recommend this course to another student (I already have!). I gained a way of looking at experiments that I will use for the rest of my time in college and, hopefully, for the rest of my life (experiments are really everywhere, so it is nice to have a critical eye). I also was able to feel successful engaging with statistical theory not covered extensively in introductory classes, and this as someone who did not take any statistics or coding classes before this one (Professor Coppock means it when he says you do not need any specific background!). It is also a great class to start learning R. Finally, it was fun!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None
Live weekly section
Leminar
The course revolved around live lectures (which were also recorded for those who could not attend synchronously) and live discussion sections.
Online section, as well.
A combination of virtual lecture and virtual seminar/discussion.
